data.title: Difference Between Simple Squamous and Stratified Squamous Epithelium | Testbook.com
data.meta_description: Discover the fundamental differences between simple squamous and stratified squamous epithelium. Learn about their structure, function, occurrence, and more.
data.text:
Introduction

Epithelial tissues play a vital role in our bodies. They form the protective outer layer of the body and line the body cavities.

Epithelial tissues are mainly divided into two categories based on the number of cell layers they possess:

Simple Epithelial Tissue

Simple epithelial tissues consist of a single layer of flattened cells that rest on a non-cellular basement membrane made of a network of fibres.

Four main types of simple epithelial tissues exist:

Simple Squamous Epithelial Tissue

Simple Cuboidal Epithelial Tissue

Simple Columnar Epithelial Tissue

Pseudo Stratified Epithelial Tissue

For more details: Tissues

Stratified Epithelial Tissue

Stratified epithelial tissues have two or more cell layers. These tissues are primarily found within the body cavity and the inner lining of organs.

Stratified epithelial tissues are further classified based on cell shape. There are three main types:

Transitional Epithelial Tissue

Stratified Squamous Epithelial Tissue

Stratified Cuboidal and Stratified Columnar Epithelial Tissue

The fundamental distinction between simple and stratified epithelial tissues is the number of cell layers. Simple epithelial tissues have a single cell layer, while stratified epithelial tissues have multiple cell layers stacked on top of each other.

Let's delve deeper into the differences between Simple and Stratified Squamous Epithelium.
